results.content: There is a coding issue that occurs in Section 3:2 that causes the site to not function when clicking the "Mastering" Icon in the admin. results.content: The teacher speaks very slowly (which fortunately is fairly well resolved by watching at 1.5x speed). The biggest issue is that the teacher is recording this on a very narrow screen, so it does not display all of his code at a given moment - he has to scroll left and right in order to see it all, so I can't ever pause and look at it and think it over, I have to keep jumping around. Sometimes he doesn't even do that, and in order to see the code you have to download it and open it in an IDE. As well, he has tooltips or something that come up and cover the text, which is just downright infuriating. Also, he types it out as he speaks, and occasionally makes typos that he doesn't notice until later and then goes back and fixes. Contrast with the courses php-mvc-from-scratch and php-mvc-login, which are just fantastic. In those, the teacher displays all of the code on screen simultaneously, allowing me to pause and look at / copy it at my leisure, there are no popups that cover any of it up, and he causes it to be displayed or not in large, pre-written chunks, so there are no typos or waiting for him to type. Further, he doesn't do a great job of explaining the functionality of a lot of the parts of the code - just saying "I did this" or "you need to do that" but not saying *why*, what specifically that part of the code is doing
results.content_html: The teacher speaks very slowly (which fortunately is fairly well resolved by watching at 1.5x speed). The biggest issue is that the teacher is recording this on a very narrow screen, so it does not display all of his code at a given moment - he has to scroll left and right in order to see it all, so I can't ever pause and look at it and think it over, I have to keep jumping around. Sometimes he doesn't even do that, and in order to see the code you have to download it and open it in an IDE. As well, he has tooltips or something that come up and cover the text, which is just downright infuriating. Also, he types it out as he speaks, and occasionally makes typos that he doesn't notice until later and then goes back and fixes. Contrast with the courses php-mvc-from-scratch and php-mvc-login, which are just fantastic. In those, the teacher displays all of the code on screen simultaneously, allowing me to pause and look at / copy it at my leisure, there are no popups that cover any of it up, and he causes it to be displayed or not in large, pre-written chunks, so there are no typos or waiting for him to type. Further, he doesn't do a great job of explaining the functionality of a lot of the parts of the code - just saying "I did this" or "you need to do that" but not saying *why*, what specifically that part of the code is doing

results.content: This was a pretty well done  for understanding basic module development for Magento 2. It claims to be agnostic to Magento 2 experience, and if you follow along the tutorials do step through the process piece by piece. However, I feel that having some previous understanding of at least how magento modules are put together really helps in understanding. That is to say, as someone who is new to Magento 2 who has struggled through understanding why are there Collection.php models in some but not all modules, why are there multiple Models with all the same name in various parts of the Model directory, how do I get a particular route to show up or how urls are generated, things of that nature. I feel I got a much better understanding and comprehension than if this was my first attempt at module development.
results.content_html: This was a pretty well done for understanding basic module development for Magento 2. It claims to be agnostic to Magento 2 experience, and if you follow along the tutorials do step through the process piece by piece. However, I feel that having some previous understanding of at least how magento modules are put together really helps in understanding. That is to say, as someone who is new to Magento 2 who has struggled through understanding why are there Collection.php models in some but not all modules, why are there multiple Models with all the same name in various parts of the Model directory, how do I get a particular route to show up or how urls are generated, things of that nature. I feel I got a much better understanding and comprehension than if this was my first attempt at module development.

results.content: No explanation of concepts.  This title should have been called:  "Learn Magento by Copying and Paste like a Monkey".  If we wanted to just copy and paste we could have just googled the topic and follow the instructions online;  it probably would have saved us time and money!  A waste of time, just watching him type and give directions; no explanation of the architecture or key concepts.  He claims to be part of the Magento Core team, yet the only example he gives is a simple "Hello World" and "Add item to a log file".  Really, I expected more from Packt Publishing.  I read their books but this video is sub-par.  Save your money, more importantly, don't waste your time by watching this video.  You'll get more by just googling the topic yourself and following the tutorials.
results.content_html: No explanation of concepts. This title should have been called: "Learn Magento by Copying and Paste like a Monkey". If we wanted to just copy and paste we could have just googled the topic and follow the instructions online; it probably would have saved us time and money! A waste of time, just watching him type and give directions; no explanation of the architecture or key concepts. He claims to be part of the Magento Core team, yet the only example he gives is a simple "Hello World" and "Add item to a log file". Really, I expected more from Packt Publishing. I read their books but this video is sub-par. Save your money, more importantly, don't waste your time by watching this video. You'll get more by just googling the topic yourself and following the tutorials.

I have taken many online courses, so far this is the worst one I have ever paid for.

results.content:
It is hard to follow him, because he does not explain what he is even trying to achieve. Most of the time his goal is not clear and only visible at the end.

In Chapter 1 - Model Layer he shows how to create a model, but he does never show how to use the model to create new items and store them in the database, even though he said he will show how to work with the model in the next video (Controller Layer) but he did not do.

He also disables security features for example in the video in Chapter 1 - Controller Layer, instead of showing how to make it work with the security feature enabled.
results.content_html:
It is hard to follow him, because he does not explain what he is even trying to achieve. Most of the time his goal is not clear and only visible at the end.

In Chapter 1 - Model Layer he shows how to create a model, but he does never show how to use the model to create new items and store them in the database, even though he said he will show how to work with the model in the next video (Controller Layer) but he did not do.

He also disables security features for example in the video in Chapter 1 - Controller Layer, instead of showing how to make it work with the security feature enabled.

results.content:
The step-by-step walkthroughs in this course are ok for review, but not much for introduction, and certainly not explanation. If I hadn't already tinkered with Magento and read a bunch of Alan Storm's blog, I think I'd feel completely lost.

If Magento 2 has you confused/overwhelmed (as it has me, coming from Ruby/Rails), I'd say check out Alan Storm's blog and Magento 2 Cookbook (from Packt, incidentally).
results.content_html:
The step-by-step walkthroughs in this course are ok for review, but not much for introduction, and certainly not explanation. If I hadn't already tinkered with Magento and read a bunch of Alan Storm's blog, I think I'd feel completely lost.

If Magento 2 has you confused/overwhelmed (as it has me, coming from Ruby/Rails), I'd say check out Alan Storm's blog and Magento 2 Cookbook (from Packt, incidentally).

Quick course with great examples that cover almost all parts of Magento 2.
Would love to see more frontend action (e.g. templates and js customization and integrations with RequireJS).

results.content: It's great. It would be even better if the instructor was tailored to match the user's selected language native accent. It was easy to understand, but just a few words that I had to hear a second time to understand. Also - this course could use a better "real world" example that uses more frontend end user elements and then dive into the admin sections later.
results.content_html: It's great. It would be even better if the instructor was tailored to match the user's selected language native accent. It was easy to understand, but just a few words that I had to hear a second time to understand. Also - this course could use a better "real world" example that uses more frontend end user elements and then dive into the admin sections later.

results.content: Der Kurs an sich ist wirklich gut, allerdings sind ist die deutsche Übersetzung schrecklich und das englisch manchmal schlecht zu verstehen.
results.content_html: Der Kurs an sich ist wirklich gut, allerdings sind ist die deutsche Übersetzung schrecklich und das englisch manchmal schlecht zu verstehen.

results.content:
Der Kurs bietet einen guten Überblick über die Programmierung in Magento2. Sergii kopiert viele Codesnippets aus seinen Vorlagen, dabei ist es oft schwierig zu folgen wenn man seine Musterlösung nicht zur Hand hat.

Ansonsten TOP Einführungskurs!

results.content: It's really really hard to understand without prior knowledge about the platform. Now don't get me wrong, I'm a Software Developer and I've used Magento for 3mo now and I still find this course confusing. The information is there but there's no context offered
results.content_html: It's really really hard to understand without prior knowledge about the platform. Now don't get me wrong, I'm a Software Developer and I've used Magento for 3mo now and I still find this course confusing. The information is there but there's no context offered

results.content: Not really what I was looking for. A from base to end course would be so much better, covering the most important parts. Now it goes from making grid to plugins to web api to I don't know what. I've never worked with Magento before, and I'd say this is not a course to follow when you begin with Magento 2.
results.content_html: Not really what I was looking for. A from base to end course would be so much better, covering the most important parts. Now it goes from making grid to plugins to web api to I don't know what. I've never worked with Magento before, and I'd say this is not a course to follow when you begin with Magento 2.

results.content: This was a really good for understanding basic module development and new concepts for Magento 2. Very useful for  Magento developers.
results.content_html: This was a really good for understanding basic module development and new concepts for Magento 2. Very useful for Magento developers.

results.content: Its good, but its not explaining much about the framework itself. Before coding in a framework like Magento 2, I think its better to learn from the scratch. Considering this tutorial is beginner's level. He is just coding and completing everything like he is completing some task. Expected more explanation than just writing code.

results.content:
Author does not explain anything, only say do this and that.. but you have no idea why. Author sims has very poor skills to teach people. Anyway If you are very experienced developer with knowing deeply few 
PHP frameworks, than you may not need that explanations. So that course seems to be for very advanced people.

results.content:
This course is bad. The teacher copy+pastes a lot of code and then just explains some of it. Also he doesn't explain why he is doing what. He misses to give us the big picture, the architecture behind it.
The examples used in the course are also just hello world level.. so it has nothing to do with "mastering". The teacher is indeed very skilled in the subject, but he misses so much explanation.. this is a good example that shows that teaching skill is also very important aside from subject skill. When you want to teach something, you have to think like students. You have to think: "When I go over this, does the student understand it?"
This is especially important in such a complex subject as magento 2, where every little detail has to be configured.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I learnt a lot of things like Rendring Ul and creating forms tab also I learnt about the web API creation. But some topics are not well explained as like Dependency Injection, Virtual Types. 

Overall it is a good tutorial however if anyone who doesn't have prior understating of Magento 2. It would be hard for them to grab maximum.

results.content:
The only reason I'm giving this course a nonzero score is because I already have some experience programming in other languages and he was able to show me how to do basic things in magento.

Unfortunately, it takes me around half an hour of exploration for every 5 mins of video content because he does not explain anything at all. 

PHPStorm helps a lot when exploring Magento as a noob. Also, have the documentation open in the side so you can get some sort of explanation about the things he copy-pastes on his code.
results.content_html:

PHPStorm helps a lot when exploring Magento as a noob. Also, have the documentation open in the side so you can get some sort of explanation about the things he copy-pastes on his code.
